text: [Music]
hello I'm UFO a cloud support engineer
here at the AWS office in Sini today I'm
going to show you how to use AWS backup
to backup and restore your Amazon
elastic file system let's get
started to back up your EFS file system
open the AWS backup console
in the navigation pen under my account
choose
settings in the service optin section
choose config resources
on the config resource page turn on EFS
and then choose
confirm choose dashboard and then choose
create ondemand
backup on the resource type menu choose
EFS then select your file system ID
in the backup window section choose
create backup now to immediately
initiate a
backup you can view your saved resource
on the protected resource page
later next enter a total retention
period value
you can also enter a transition to code
storage
value for total retention period select
days and then enter the number of days
that you want to retain the backup for
backup W select one of the pre-existing
W or choose create new W if you are
creating a new W then provide details to
create it
for IM row choose default row if you
want to assign tags choose add tag and
then enter a key and
value then choose create on demand
backup
finally on the jobs page select the
backup job ID for your resource to
confirm that the backup job status
changed to
completed to restore your EFS file
system open the AWS backup
console in the navigation pan choose WS
select your backup W and then select the
latest completed
backup choose actions and then choose
restore next configure your restore
settings such as restore type restore
location file system type performance
mode encryption and IM role
then choose restore backup
enter the restore jobs tab on the jobs
page check the restore job
status after you are finished open the
EFS console to view your restored file
system
you can now mount the restored file
system on an Amazon EC2 instance to
access the
files so now you know how to use AWS
backup to backup and restore your Amazon
EFS file
system thanks for watching and happy
cloud computing from all of us here at
AWS
